body_html:
I'm going to second @allentran 's comment: It really depends on the audience. If I translate the spirit of @hartsantler 's comment, I might reformulate this issue into two separate ones:
(1) Improve the clarity of the intro tutorial in ways that don't make it excessively fluffy for its current audience of people with some existing familiarity with machine learning concepts and math;
and
(2) "It would be great to write an intro tutorial for tensorflow for non-machine-learning people." 2, if I'm translating correctly, would actually be a combo "here's some basic machine learning" and "we're doing it in tensorflow". Brett, does that roughly capture the spirit of what you're thinking?

I can think if some ways to do 1 -- the comment before W and b, for example, could say "construct a linear model with bias b and weights W" without reducing concision much, but which would help clarify what's going on. I'll see if I can find a few ways to do a bit of that without going all the way to 2.
